required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 10, 2017
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIT) While in a Hyperoxic-Hyperbaric Environment on Exercise Performance
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIT) While in a Hyperoxic-Hyperbaric Environment on Exercise Performance (HITOP Study)

brief_summary.textblock: Hyperbaric oxygen has previously been tested as a possible means for pre-conditioning to enhance exercise performance. This study is designed to examine the effects of exercising in a hyperbaric chamber for improving fitness when combined with high-intensity training.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in maximum VO2 at 2 weeks compared to baseline

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in VO2 measured at anaerobic threshold (in mL O2/kg/min) at 2 weeks compared to baseline
ΔVO2/ΔWR (in mL O2/kg/min/Watt; a measure of exercise efficiency)
Change in peak work rate (in Watts) at 2 weeks compared to baseline
Change in heart rate response to exercise at 2 weeks compared with baseline
Change in level of perceived exertion at 2 weeks compared with baseline
Change in Borg dyspnea score at 2 weeks compared with baseline

arm_group.description: High intensity training will be completed while the subjects are breathing normal air.
The high intensity training program will be carried out in a hyperbaric chamber.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy individuals, ages 18-40 years that are sedentary or recreationally active but not involved in any structured endurance training will be eligible for the study. This level of activity will be defined as performing mild-moderate aerobic exercise 0-3 times per week.
- VO2 max within normal limits (defined as 84-120% predicted using Wasserman reference equations48).
- Spirometry within predicted limits.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects unable to complete a satisfactory VO2 max test
- Individuals with chronic cardiovascular disease such as hypertension, valve disease, coronary artery disease, cardiac conduction abnormalities, etc.
- History of pneumothorax or chronic lung disease such as asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis
- Active Smokers
- Pregnant women
- Persons unable to read or understand English, not in their full mental capacity or who are blind.
